Curriculum vitae
ARTHUR ALEXANDER BARDOS, born April 26, 1921, in Budapest, ’Tungary,
Naturalized citizen of the U.S. December 30, 1943* Married, no children,
Protestant,
Education: Graduated from secondary school with highest honors in Budapest,
Hungary, A.B, in Cinematography: University of Southern California, 1943*
M,A, in Comparative Literature: University of Southern California, 1948,
Course work and general examinations completed, with thesis in progress,for
Ph, D, at Harvard, 1951,
Languages: Fluent in German, French, and Hungarian.
Military service: 1943-1946r U.S. Amy Air Force, Amy Specialized Training
Program, Psychological Warfare Division - SHftBF. Discharged with the rating
of Technician 3rd grade. 1949-1952, 2d Lt., Military Intelligence Reserve,
Teaching: 1946-1948: Teaching assistant in German, University of Sovthem
California. 1948-1951: Torching fellow in German, Harvard University,
B-rnadcflgtlng; While in military service, was assigned to the German service of
Radio Luxembourg during its operation as the official voice of SHAEF; diJ in¬
telligence analysis and prisoner of war interrogations; wrote and spoke political
and military commentaries; wrote features and radio plays for translation ?nto
German or broadcasting in English; was assistant editor and editor, respectively,
of youth and farm programs. After a year at Radio Luxembourg, was transferred
as Associate Features Editor, to Radio Frankfurt, then center of the "South
German Network," serving the American Zone of Germany; discharged from military
service and employed by the War Department to continue to work at Radio Frank¬
furt.
1945-1946: As editor, then Control Officer and, finally, acting
Chief of Station, participated in setting up what is now the "Hessian Radio,"
in selecting and training a new programming staff, 5n introducing to Germany
such radio techniques as round tables, newsreels, etc., and in organizing the
first post-war German "school of the air. " Resigned position in order to
pursue graduate work,
1951 to present: Radio Program Officer at the American Embassy in
Vienna, in charge of program operations for the three-station (210 kw) Red-White-
Red network, covering most of Austria. While in this position, has worked for
closer cooperation between RWR and other European Eroadcasting organizations,
introduced such programs as the "RWR World News Roundup" and "Arthur Meets the
Critic" to Austria, contributed to the greater political activation of the net¬
work in the U. S, interest. Was during a recent five-month period acting Radio
Officer, charged with full responsibility for the operation of the network.
